- Turkey has not ticked off all the requirements on the Roadmap set. See http://avrupa.info.tr/de/visas-mobility-migration/eu-turkey-dialogue-on-visas-mobility-migration.html
- The process of ratification once those have been ticked will take time.
- The agreement will come into effect at least a full month after ratification: "The provisions of the agreement related to the readmission of the nationals of the two sides, and those related to the readmission of the stateless persons and nationals from third countries with which Turkey has concluded bilateral treaties or arrangements on readmission, will enter into force on the first day of the second month following the date on which the EU and Turkey will notify each other that their respective ratification procedures have been completed. " - citation from same document
- The EU parliament has one more session in which it possibly could ratify such an agreement.

Turkey seems to be moving further from the EU and it probably helps Erdogan's domestic image that he can show that the EU does not understand Turkey's problems (that Erdogan and most Turks believe requires a crackdown on anyone who does not agree with Erdogan). Like Putin, Erdogan believes that countries need to be ruled, not lead. So Erdogan will not meet the EU conditions for Visa free travel. The EU has many voters who feel that the last thing that the EU needs is visa free travel from a large Muslim country, so for the EU it is convenient that Turkey has not met the visa free travel conditions (72 in total). If the EU allowed Turks visa free travel without Turkey complying it would look very weak. Turkey could scrap the refugee agreement with the EU, but besides the visa free travel clause it included money from the EU. Therefore its possible that an "adjustment" to the deal (e.g. more money from the EU to Turkey) will compensate for the visa free travel.
Erdogan seems in the mood to play double or nothing. At minimum they'll get some temporary deal out of it while the parliament(s) keep debating.

Juncker reconfirmed that Turkey has to meet the criteria first before gaining visa free travel allowance. Erdogan is trying hard to put pressure on him as it is also a way for him to show to his electorate what he can achieve. He should not be underestimated but his power may not be enough to get the visa free travel agreement done this year.

Political instability in Turkey last week changed my prediction.

This is a tough one. The EU needs to be seen as upholding its part of the deal with Turkey on migrants, but Erdogan's expected heavy-handed response to the failed coup will make this already unpopular in Europe action even more difficult. The process will be governed by: (i) Turkey's progress toward satisfying the formal requirements set in the March deal; (ii) the political climate in the EU, and (iii) Erdogan's response to the coup. While there is a considerable uncertainty about all these three factors, overall the EU will have to give the matter serious consideration if they want to keep the migrants in Turkey.

The recent coup attempt and the subsequent crackdown in Turkey is likely to make the EU less inclined to lift the requirements, because of the human rights issues, to say nothing of the increasing ISIS presence in Turkey, which might lead to terrorists traveling into the EU more easily with no visa restrictions. The EU is between a rock and a hard place when it comes to Turkish treatment of migrants from the Middle East, however. It is unclear how the deal with Turkey, predicated on lifting the visa restrictions, will break down, but Erdogan might just turn the migrants in Turkey's camps loose to flood the borders. That would be, ummm, a very unpalatable turn of events for the EU.

The recent Brexit vote has brought to the forefront the underlying frailties of the European Union as an institution - UK voters voting for 'Leave' stated immigration as one of the major problems with the EU. Although these are at face value entirely different questions I think they both strike at the heart of a certain undercurrent rumbling through the Union at the moment. There is after all a reason far right parties are gaining votes in France, Austria, etc. The general population are far less open to the idea of free movement of labour than the leaders that are running their respective countries, especially so after the Syria crisis. This isn't something that looks like it is going to end and many people believe Turkey is the portal to Europe. As long as that is the case and as long as certain politicians have reelection campaigns (Merkel in particular), I doubt we will see anything that looks like they are accommodating taking more people into the EU.

I was wrong about this question on the first go round. I predicted Brexit and see the EU falling apart, and so i thought EU would lift the Turkey requirements in order to increase its odds of survival. They did not see Brexit coming. How soon will a potential collapse require the EU to act to buttress itself, and will the EU recognize it when it sees it? the fallout of Brexit will have to happen quickly if their hand is forced. I dont see it happening soon enough, though i still believe my rationale is correct--the EU will do it as a desperation move to stave off a near-term collapse if needed. The near term may not be near enough.
